name: Hirosaki Cherry Blossom Festival
short_description: One of Japan's top 3 cherry blossom spots with 2,600 trees.
description:
The Hirosaki Cherry Blossom Festival is held in Hirosaki Park, surrounding the historic Hirosaki Castle. The park is home to over 2,600 cherry trees, including some of the oldest Somei Yoshino trees in Japan. The event is famous for its 'Hanaikada' (flower rafts), where fallen petals completely carpet the castle moats in pink.

At night, the trees and the castle keep are illuminated, creating a surreal reflection on the water. Visitors can also enjoy rental boats in the moat to see the blossoms from a unique perspective. It is widely considered the premier cherry blossom viewing experience in Northern Japan.

name: Aomori Nebuta Festival
short_description: Giant glowing paper floats and energetic dancing.
description:
The Nebuta Festival is one of the Three Great Festivals of Tohoku and a UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage. It features massive, hand-painted washi paper floats depicting mythical figures and kabuki actors, which are illuminated from within and paraded through the streets. The parade is accompanied by 'Haneto' dancers who jump and chant 'Rassera!' to the beat of taiko drums.

History suggests the festival originated from the Tanabata 'floating of lanterns' tradition, intended to wash away sleepiness (nebutai) before the harvest. On the final night, the floats are placed on boats in the harbor for a sea parade accompanied by a massive fireworks display.

name: Naruko Gorge Autumn Foliage
short_description: A deep V-shaped gorge famous for vibrant maples and oaks.
description:
Naruko Gorge is one of Tohoku's most iconic autumn leaf destinations. The 100-meter-deep cliffs are covered in a dense mix of maples, oaks, and beeches that turn brilliant shades of orange and red. The most famous view is of the Ofukazawa Bridge spanning the gorge, especially when a JR train emerges from the mountain tunnel below.

Visitors can enjoy the scenery from the Naruko Gorge Rest House observation deck or walk the Naruko Gorge Trail. The area is also part of the Naruko Onsen village, making it a perfect spot to combine foliage viewing with a soak in traditional hot springs.

name: SENDAI Pageant of Starlight
description:
The Pageant of Starlight is one of Japan's most famous winter illumination events. Hundreds of zelkova trees lining the Jozenji-dori and Aoba-dori avenues are draped in over 600,000 warm-toned LED lights. The effect is a 'tunnel of light' that transforms the city center into a winter wonderland.

A highlight of the event is the 'Starlight Wink,' where all lights are briefly turned off and then re-lit simultaneously several times a night. There is also a 'Santa's Forest' parade featuring hundreds of participants in holiday costumes. This event has been a symbol of Sendai's resilience and community spirit since it began in 1986.

name: Yokote Kamakura Snow Festival
description:
The Yokote Kamakura Festival features over 100 large snow huts (kamakura) and thousands of miniature ones scattered across the city. Inside the large huts, children invite passersby to share grilled rice cakes (mochi) and sweet rice wine (amazake) while praying to the water deity for a good harvest and the safety of their families.

At night, the riverbank is lined with thousands of tiny snow domes, each lit by a single candle, creating a sea of flickering lights against the snow. The tradition dates back over 450 years and is a hallmark of the snowy 'Ura-Nippon' (Back-of-Japan) culture.
